coredata.dc:title: Enhanced CH4 yields by interfacial heating-induced hot water steam during photocatalytic CO2 reduction
coredata.dc:creator: Hu, Xiantao
Xie, Zhanjun
Tang, Qian
Wang, Heng
Zhang, Lianbin
Wang, Jingyu
coredata.dc:description: The adsorption and activation of H2O vapor on photocatalyst is highly important for CO2 reduction yet having been overlooked among the large amounts of reports. Herein, we demonstrate a preferential H2O adsorption mechanism to replace the previously assumed competitive adsorption, that is, H2O molecules were pre-adsorbed on the catalytic sites and dissociated to provide protons for the activation of the adsorbed CO2 molecules. Thanks to a photothermal membrane (PM)-induced interfacial heating, the generation of hot steam dramatically increases the partial pressure of water vapor from 17 to 43 kPa at ambient pressure, which favors H2O adsorption on TiO2 surface. The well-designed TiO2+PM system achieves selective reduction of CO2 to CH4 with a high evolution rate of 18.3 μmol g−1 h−1, about 3.3 times of that in the absence of PM. The light-to-heat conversion makes the utilization of light energy more efficient, not merely for the photogeneration of charge carriers.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Photocatalytic CO2 reduction
H2O adsorption
Photothermal membrane
Water steam
Solid-gas reaction

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Schematic apparatus for photocatalytic CO2 conversion assisted by photothermal membrane.

Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of (a) Airlaid paper and (b) PPy/Airlaid paper. (c) Changes of temperature at the surface of PPy/Airlaid paper under light illumination of varied intensities. (d) Infrared images of PPy/Airlaid paper during light illumination. (e) Solar to evaporation energy conversion efficiency and evaporation rate of different optical density.
(a) XRD pattern, (b) TEM and (c, d) HRTEM images of TiO2 photocatalyst. The vertical column in (a) is the standard pattern (65-5714) of TiO2 crystal.

Time-dependent evolution rate of (a) CH4 and (b) CO products in the systems of PM, TiO2, and TiO2+PM. The photocatalytic reactions were carried out in a batch system under standard atmospheric pressure and light illumination. (c) Cycling test of photocatalytic CO2 conversion in the TiO2+PM system.

(a) Monitoring of temperature on the photocatalyst surface in the reactor after turning on 300 W Xe lamp. Light intensity: I P = 2.0 kW m−2 on PPy membrane surface; I C = 5.0 kW m−2 on TiO2 catalyst surface. Infrared camera images of TiO2 surface in (b) TiO2 and (c) TiO2+PM systems. (d) Temperature-dependent kinetic analysis of CH4 production rate. TiO2 catalysts were surrounded by the circulating water in a jacketed reactor to adjust the temperature. (e) EIS and (f) photocurrent response of TiO2 at 25 °C, 30 °C and 45 °C.

(a) Comparison in GC spectra of CH4 and CO products in the TiO2+PM system between with and without adding water. (b) Comparison in gas evolution rate in the reaction systems between with and without adding water. (c) Influence of partial pressure of H2O vapor on the CH4 evolution rate over TiO2 photocatalysts under light irradiation. (d) Plot of gas evolution rate as function of p H2O in TiO2+PM system. Solid line: changes in CH4 and CO production rates by adjusting I p from 1.0 to 2.5 kW m−2. Dot line: changes in CH4 and CO production rates by temperature of PM. (e) Changes in gas temperature in the reactor and (f) comparison of CH4 production rate under different conditions of water vapor. In (e, f), the orange and blue lines are the results under normal conditions of TiO2 and TiO2+M; the green and red lines refer to the hot H2O vapor with similar temperature to that in TiO2+M system being injected into the reaction system and the difference between green and red lines are that hot H2O vapor was continuously heating during the photocatalytic reaction or not. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article).

Effect of the CO2 concentration on the CH4 and CO evolution rates in (a) TiO2 and (b) TiO2+M systems. The partial pressure of water vapor was kept constant and N2 was used as balance gas. (c) Average rate of O2 evolution from the photocatalytic systems during 3 h of light illumination.

head.ce:title: Enhanced CH4 yields by interfacial heating-induced hot water steam during photocatalytic CO2 reduction

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry for Energy Conversion and Storage (Ministry of Education), School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, 430074, Hubei, PR China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry for Energy Conversion and Storage (Ministry of Education)
School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering
Huazhong University of Science and Technology

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry for Energy Conversion and Storage (Ministry of Education), School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan 430074, Hubei (PR China)

ce:footnote.ce:note-para: These authors contributed equally to this work.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The adsorption and activation of H2O vapor on photocatalyst is highly important for CO2 reduction yet having been overlooked among the large amounts of reports. Herein, we demonstrate a preferential H2O adsorption mechanism to replace the previously assumed competitive adsorption, that is, H2O molecules were pre-adsorbed on the catalytic sites and dissociated to provide protons for the activation of the adsorbed CO2 molecules. Thanks to a photothermal membrane (PM)-induced interfacial heating, the generation of hot steam dramatically increases the partial pressure of water vapor from 17 to 43 kPa at ambient pressure, which favors H2O adsorption on TiO2 surface. The well-designed TiO2+PM system achieves selective reduction of CO2 to CH4 with a high evolution rate of 18.3 μmol g−1 h−1, about 3.3 times of that in the absence of PM. The light-to-heat conversion makes the utilization of light energy more efficient, not merely for the photogeneration of charge carriers.

ce:section.ce:para: Nowadays, the increasing CO2 emission in the atmosphere by the depletion of carbon-rich fossil fuels has caused serious social issues including the destruction of ecological balance and the shortage of carbonaceous resources. Inspired by natural photosynthesis, the photocatalytic technique has been explored as a promising strategy to address the issues by utilizing abundant solar energy to convert CO2 into valuable fuels [1–6]. Among the existing photocatalytic systems, two approaches, i.e., gas-phase and liquid-phase reactions, have been developed for CO2 conversion. In the liquid-phase reaction, metal complexes and metal–organic frameworks are usually employed as the photocatalysts which realized high catalytic reactivity towards CO2 reduction [7–9]. However, the reduction can only occur in the anhydrous or less water system containing organic sacrificial reagent to overcome the sluggish kinetics of oxidation process, especially for the fact that CO is the main product and hydrocarbon fuel generation is quite limited [10–12]. Moreover, the presence of carbon-containing sacrificial donors brought uncertainties in quantifying the reduction yield since they could also contribute to the reduction products or participate in the reduction process in an indirect way [13,14].

In contrast, the photocatalytic CO2 reduction with H2O vapor under gas-phase conditions is more attractive because it favors the high selectivity to hydrocarbon production and the reagents are completely green and rich in nature [15–18]. Meanwhile the merits of stability and recyclability of the solid-gas catalysis make it applicable in industrial production if the main obstacle, i.e. relatively low conversion efficiency, can be overcome. To tackle this issue, numerous efforts have been focused on the improvement of light absorption and charge carriers separation of photocatalysts [19–26]. Most recently, the CO2 adsorption on the catalyst surface has been gradually realized as the crucial step in the whole reaction process [27–30]. There are increasing reports on the combination of photocatalysts with microporous materials due to their superior specific surface area and CO2 uptake ability, leading to the enhanced CO2 conversion efficiency [31–35].

As another reactant molecule, the H2O vapor also plays an important role in the CO2 reduction reaction due to its contribution to the oxidation cycle. Even its presence is known to be essential, the impact of H2O vapor on the efficiency of CO2 reduction has always been overlooked in comparison to the large amounts of works related to the development of various photocatalysts [13]. Actually, it has been proved that the dissociation of H2O on the catalyst surface is the first step of CO2 activation by providing protons to react with the surface adsorbed CO2 molecules [36–38]. That is, the CO2 reduction efficiency is normally restricted by the kinetically sluggish water oxidation cycle [39]. As discovered in our previous study, the photocatalytic activity of the whole process strongly depended on the content of H2O vapor and CH4 evolution rate obviously increased with the humidity [40]. In addition, the comparison of competitive adsorption demonstrated that the pre-adsorption of water did not affect the CO2 adsorption ability or the photocatalytic efficiency [27,39]. It can be deduced that the overall reaction will be accelerated if increasing the H2O coverage with co-adsorption of CO2 on the photocatalyst.

Aiming at increasing H2O coverage and reaction kinetics in the CO2 reduction process, herein we employed the photothermal membrane (PM) as the first example of combination with photocatalytic CO2 conversion, through which the interfacial heating-produced hot water steam dramatically promoted the reduction of CO2. The scheme of PM-assisted TiO2 photocatalysis (TiO2+PM) for CO2 reduction is illustrated in Fig. 1 . PM was completely wetted and adhered to the reactor wall to realize the spatial isolation from TiO2 photocatalyst. In this way, it can receive the scattered light and then generate hot water steam in the system by the photothermal effect. Meanwhile, the location of PM avoids the light shielding and direct heating of TiO2 surface. The PM-assisted photocatalytic strategy can effectively accelerate H2O evaporation to increase H2O coverage on the catalyst surface without extra energy consumption and therefore enhance the efficiency and selectivity for CH4 yields.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis of polypyrrole coated Airlaid paper (PPy/Airlaid paper)
ce:section.ce:para: 1.13 μL of FeCl3·6H2O aqueous solution was added into the pyrrole aqueous solution, and then the airlaid paper was placed on the solution surface. With the initiation of Fe3+, the pyrrole monomers polymerized on the Airlaid paper surface to form the polypyrrole coated Airlaid paper. After reacting for 30 min, the PPy/Airlaid paper was separated from the solution and washed several times with ethanol. Finally, the resultant PPy/Airlaid paper was dried in an oven for 5 h under 40 °C.

TiO2 photocatalyst was synthesized using the lamellar protonated titanate (LPT) as a precursor. The mixture containing tetrabutyl titanate (9 mL) and absolute ethanol (66 mL) was slowly added into deionized water (90 mL) under magnetic agitation. When the mixture was completely added, the resulted suspension was heated to 70 °C and stirred mechanically for about 2 h until it was viscous. Then 1 M NaOH (300 mL) was added into the condensed suspension and was stirred at 70 °C under mechanical stirring for 12 h. LPT was obtained and washed repeatedly by deionized water. LPT precursor (9 g) were dispersed into isopropyl alcohol (6 mL) and stirred for 40 min. Next, fluoric acid (0.5 mL) was added into the above suspension to synthesizeTiO2 photocatalyst after 12 h of solvethermal treatment at 180 °C.

The morphology was obtained on microscopes including field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Hitachi SU8010) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Tecnai G2 F30). Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were monitored on a VERTEX 70. The Pyris1 TGA (PerkinElmer Instruments) was used to test the thermogravimetric curves of samples. The infrared camera (MAG32, Shanghai Magnity Electronics CO., Ltd) was settled to monitor the temperature on the photocatalyst surface. The measurements of contact angle were performed on an OCA 15EC system. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD, SmartLab-SE) was used to record the crystal structures of as-prepared samples. UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectrum (DRS) was conducted on a UV–vis spectrophotometer (UV-3600, Shimadzu, Japan) with BaSO4 power as a reflectance standard. N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms were examined using an ASAP 2020 (Micromeritics Instruments, USA). Electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) under different temperature was carried out in a 0.1 M electrolyte solution containing KCl, K3Fe(CN)6 and K4Fe(CN)6. The photocurrent responses of as-prepared samples under different temperature were measured in a 0.1 M Na2SO4 solution using the electrochemical workstation (CHI650E, Chenhua) equipped with a three-electrode system and constant temperature water bath.

Photocatalytic performance toward CO2 conversion over the synthesized catalysts was tested in a sealed batch reactor under mild condition. The volume of such a sealed container for photocatalytic reaction is 350 mL. The customized photocatalytic reactor was equipped with water jacket and circulating water pump. Thus the temperature of the water vapor in the reactor can be adjusted by the circulating water inside the water jacket. A 300 W Xe lamp (PLS-SXE300D, Beijing Perfectlight, China) was used as the light source. The full spectrum of the Xe lamp is shown in Fig. S1, showing the range of main wavelength as 325∼780 nm. Before reaction, 50 mg of catalyst powders were placed on the glass dish that positioned 5 cm of distance under light source. PPy/Airlaid paper was tailored to a square with a side length of 4.5 cm and exposed area of 20.25 cm2, which was placed vertically inside the sealed reactor. The average light intensity, calculated from the measured values of four corners of PPy/Airlaid paper, was used to quantify the light intensity arriving at the paper which could be adjusted by the power of light source. PPy/Airlaid paper were positioned 3 cm of distance below the glass dish. The deionized water (2 mL) was injected into the PPy/Airlaid paper. Before the light irradiation, the photocatalytic reactor was thoroughly vacuum-treated, then CO2 gas was introduced into the circulation system. The gas products from the reduction reaction were analyzed by gas chromatography (GC-2014C, Shimadzu Corp. Japan) equipped with thermal conductivity detector (TCD) for H2 detection and flame ionization detector (FID) for CO and CH4 detections. To eliminate the oxygen interference by the air, the O2 product from the oxidation reaction was monitored by an optic fiber oxygen sensor (Ocean-Optics), which was sealed in the photocatalytic reactor to be isolated from the surrounding environment. The cycling test of photocatalytic CO2 conversion was conducted by recording the gas evolution rates of five cycles under identical conditions. After each cycle, TiO2 photocatalyst was dried in a vacuum oven to remove the surface adsorbed water and PPy/Airlaid paper was wet again by the deionized water.

The membrane containing photothermal material is considered to be an effective technique for solar-driven hot steam generation. Polypyrrole (PPy) as a promising conductive polymer shows wide light absorption from ultraviolet to near infrared light and an excellent photothermal transduction [41]. PPy decorated Airlaid paper as a typical PM material was introduced into the photocatalytic system. The PPy membrane, synthesized by in situ polymerization of pyrrole on the Airlaid paper, presents a rough outmost surface by the uniform decoration of PPy nanoparticles, relative to a rather smooth surface of the paper substrate (Fig. 2 a, b). Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of both Airlaid paper and PPy/Airlaid paper display the characteristic absorption bands of OH, CH, CO, CO, and CC groups due to the existence of cellulose (Fig. S2) [42]. Differently, two absorption peaks of CN (923 cm−1) and CC in pyrrole ring (1555 cm−1) emerged in PPy/Airlaid paper [41], both of which confirmed the coating of paper surface with PPy membrane. As a photothermal membrane, the thermal stability of the PPy/Airlaid paper should be considered in terms of the durability and recyclability of the photocatalytic system. The thermogravimetric (TG) analysis shows the good stability of pristine paper substrate with or without PPy membrane at the temperature lower than 250 °C in air atmosphere (Fig. S3). The temperature at the surface of dry PPy/Airlaid paper was measured to be 76∼113 °C under light illumination with intensity varying from 1.0 to 2.5 kW m-2 (Fig. 2c, d). Thus the structure stability of the photothermal membrane can be unchanged under normal operating conditions. The surface hydrophilicity of the material is considered to be an important factor in the interfacial heating-induced hot water steam production. The water contact angles of PPy/Airlaid paper and Airlaid paper reach 0 ° (Fig. S4). The result indicates the excellent hydrophilicity of PPy membrane after coating Airlaid paper, which ensures the sufficient water supply during the water steam production. The steam generation performance of the photothermal membrane was also evaluated by recording time-dependent mass change and the corresponding evaporation rate under solar radiation (Figs. S5 and 2 e). Under 2.0 kW m-2 of light illumination, the evaporation efficiency reached 60.1 %, suggesting the excellent steam generation performance of PPy/Airlaid paper [43–46]. The cycling test confirmed that the PPy membrane well maintained the evaporation performance within five repeated cycles (Fig. S6), which suggested its applicable to the long-term reaction.

Having confirmed the interfacial heating-induced water steam production on PPy membrane, we used it to provide more H2O vapor for participating in the photocatalytic reduction of CO2 over TiO2 catalysts. TiO2 photocatalysts were prepared from the lamellar protonated titanate precursor according to our previous report [27,47]. The crystal structure, morphology, and surface properties were investigated by XRD, TEM, DRS and N2 adsorption–desorption measurements. All the diffraction peaks in Fig. 3 a can be assigned to the anatase phase of TiO2 crystals, according to the standard pattern (65-5714). TEM and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) observations in Fig. 3b and c present the well-defined corners and edges of TiO2 catalysts. The crystal lattice spacing of 0.352 and 0.235 nm corresponds to the {101} and {001} facets and the interfacial angle of them is 68.3 ° (Fig. 3d), which confirmed the formation of nanosized anatase TiO2 crystals with coexposed {101} and {001} facets. DRS in Fig. S7 displays that the light absorption edge of TiO2 photocatalysts extends up to 389 nm, within the light wavelength of Xe lamp. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm of TiO2 photocatalyst is typical type IV, which provides a high value of specific surface area as 118 m2 g−1 consisting of a narrow mesopore size distribution of 4.86 nm (Fig. S8).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Evaluation of photocatalytic activity and stability
ce:section.ce:para: Photocatalytic CO2 reduction was carried out in a solid-gas catalytic system under 2.0 kW m−2 of light illumination using H2O vapor as electron donors. In the photocatalytic system, the main products, CH4 and CO, were obtained through the 8-electron and 2-electron reduction pathways, respectively. The signal of H2 product in the gas chromatography spectrum was not detectable (Fig. S9), which indicated that the dissociation of H2O provided protons for CO2 reduction rather than be reduced to produce H2. In comparison to a considerable amount of H2 evolution from the liquid reactants [48–52], the gas photocatalytic system is beneficial to suppress the side reaction of H2O reduction and improve the selectivity for CO2 conversion. Fig. 4 a, b shows the time-course CH4 and CO evolution in the systems of PM, TiO2, and TiO2+PM. Table S1 presents the average gas evolution rates and electron consumption (R e). The TiO2 photocatalysts present average evolution rates of 5.5 μmol g-1 h-1 for CH4 and 3.6 μmol g-1 h-1 for CO, close to the results of our previous reports [17,44]. Interestingly, the introduction of PM dramatically increased the efficiency of CO2 reduction over TiO2 photocatalysts, especially for the selective production of CH4 showing about 3.3 times of the original yields (18.3 μmol g-1 h-1). It is noted that the CO production are extremely low (<1 μmol g-1 h-1) in the reaction system only containing PM (no TiO2 photocatalysts). Such low CO product may come from the slight decomposition of PM under illumination. The results suggest that PM cannot function as catalysts for CO2 conversion but exert a positive influence on the photocatalytic process. The signal of m/z = 17 in the isotopic labeling experiment can be corresponded to 13CH4 (Fig. S10), confirming the origin of the product from CO2 conversion. The signals of m/z = 16 and 15 probably come from the fragments of 13CH4 together with those from the pre-adsorbed 12CO2 on the surface of catalyst. Fig. 4c displays the cyclic conversion efficiency of TiO2+PM system during five consecutive runs. The negligible changes in evolution rates of products suggest the excellent durability of PM material and photocatalyst for a long-term reaction. The structural characterizations of the recycled TiO2 catalysts in Figs. S11 and S12 further demonstrate the stability of crystal phase and chemical structure after the reaction.

To clarify the effect of the photothermal membrane in light-to-heat conversion and water steam generation, we systematically study the influence of temperature and water vapor on the CO2 conversion efficiency over TiO2 photocatalysts. In the batch reactor, the temperature of gas mixture (T G) rises quickly and then reaches a steady state under light illumination. It is found that the introduction of PM leads to an obvious increase in T G from 56 to 78 °C (Fig. S13). Accordingly, the surface temperature of catalysts (T C) in TiO2+PM system reached 86 °C, much higher than that in the TiO2 system (73 °C, Fig. 5 a–c). Since PM is spatially isolated from TiO2 photocatalysts in the reactor, and it cannot directly heat them via their physical contact but the thermal energy can be transferred from the PM-induced hot H2O vapor. Consistent with the results of steam evaporation, the evolution rates of CH4 and CO increased with the light intensity arriving at the PM surface (I P) even though the light intensity at the photocatalyst surface (I C) was kept unchanged (Fig. S14). The results indicated that PM-induced steam evaporation both increased T G and T C values, which might exhibit a combined effect on the CO2 conversion.

An apparent influence of the elevated temperature lies in increasing the kinetic energy of CO2 and H2O molecules on the catalyst surface. Thus the reaction can be accelerated by the existence of more activated molecules at the surface catalytic sites. In light of the linear increase in CH4 concentration with irradiation time, its production rate constant (k) can be calculated based on a pseudo-zero order model. The temperature-dependent kinetics experiment was conducted using circulating water flowing around the photocatalyst to avoid the photothermal effect of PM on T C. The Arrhenius plot in Fig. 5d clearly demonstrated that the elevation of the surface temperature of photocatalyst favored the reduction of CO2 to CH4 product. EIS in Fig. 5e display the effect of temperature on the electronic conductivity of TiO2 electrode. The radius of TiO2 decreased with the increase of temperature, which indicated the more efficient charge transfer at higher temperature. The improved interfacial charge transfer by temperature can be further confirmed by photocurrent measurement (Fig. 5f). The photocurrent response gradually increased when elevating the temperature from 25 °C to 30 °C and 45 °C respectively. The results illustrated that the higher temperature could facilitate the transport of photogenerated charge carriers, leading to the higher yields of effective electrons for CO2 reducion.

On the other hand, even at the same degree of T C, the k value of CH4 production is higher in the TiO2+PM system than that in the TiO2 system (Fig. 5d). It is noted that the PM-induced difference in T C (73 → 86 °C) can only cause ∼ 20 % of increase in CH4 evolution rate based on the Arrhenius plot. Hence the dramatically improved reaction rate in TiO2+PM system suggests the non-negligible effect of ambient medium surrouding the catalysts. Actually, the PM-induced light-to-heat conversion promoted the water evaporation to produce more H2O vapor in the reactor. Then the role of the partial pressure of H2O in the photocatalytic CO2 reduction process should be discussed separately from the temperature. Without the addition of water, the evolution rate of CH4 on TiO2 declined to 9 % of the original value (5.5 → 0.5 μmol g−1 h−1), while the evolution rate of CO showed a slight increase to 4.4 μmol g−1 h−1. The obvious changes in CH4 and CO evolution rates were also observed in TiO2+PM system (Fig. 6 a, b). In this case, the electron donor presumably comes from the pre-adsorbed H2O on the vessel and catalyst surface. Normally, the reduction of CO2 to CH4 is relatively difficult due to the requirements of accepting eight electrons and eight protons. Therefore, the low concentration of H2O vapor cannot provide enough electrons and protons, which restricted the CH4 evolution. With increasing the partial pressure of H2O vapor (p H2O), the CH4 evolution rate in TiO2 system almost increased linearly in a wide range of p H2O = 2∼17 kPa (Fig. 6c). In heterogeneous catalytic system, the reaction rate is proportional to the fractional coverage of each reactant on the surface catalytic sites (Eq. (1)). With regard to solid-gas phase catalysis, the coverage of gaseous reactant depends on its partial pressure in gas mixture. There are two gaseous reactants involved in the reaction, i.e. CO2 and H2O, which were reported to present a competitive adsorption mode with a different adsorption-desorption equilibrium constant on the catalyst surface [53,54], to produce the main products as CH4, CO, and O2. The relationship between the reaction rate and fraction of sites coverage can be established using Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism (Eq. (2)).

Where r is the reaction rate, Ɵ represents the fractional coverage of gaseous reactant on the active sites of catalyst surface, p and K are the partial pressure and adsorption-desorption equilibrium constant for each reactant and detectable product, respectively. The Eq. (2) can be simplified to Eq. (3) based on the following assumptions: (a) the adsorption-desorption equilibrium constant of H2O (K H2O) is proved to be much lower than that of CO2 (K CO2) on the TiO2 surface [53,54]; (b) the yield of CO is extremely low even it can be moderately adsorbed; (c) the yields of CH4 and O2 are low and both of them are weakly adsorbed.

According to Eq. (3), r is proportional to the partial pressure of H2O under constant I C, T C, and p CO2. Thus, such a simple kinetic model clearly demonstrates the linear relationship between CH4 evolution rate and p H2O in the TiO2 system, as shown in Fig. 6c. As above-mentioned, the introduction of PM into the TiO2 system significantly improved the generation of the hot water. The elevated temperature accordingly lead to a higher saturated vapor pressure, i.e. higher p H2O in TiO2+PM system than that in TiO2 system. Further, the value of p H2O in TiO2+PM system can be directly regulated by I P when keeping I C unchanged. Through adjusting the value of I P from 1.0 to 2.0 kW m−2, the T G was measured to be 63∼78 °C, corresponding to the p H2O varying from 22∼43 kPa. It is found that the plot of both CH4 and CO evolution rates nearly shows linearity as a function of p H2O (solid line in Fig. 6d). Among them, the CH4 production shows a much steeper slope, which suggests that more H2O vapor favors the selective reduction of CO2 to CH4 relative to CO product. Another approach was adopted for adjusting p H2O just by controlling the temperature of circulating water flowing around the reactor while I P was kept unchanged. The changes in production rates of both CH4 and CO with gas temperature were plotted as dot line in Fig. 6d. Interestingly, these two kinds of lines highly overlapped each other, which indicated that PM mostly functioned as the source of hot H2O vapor for CO2 to CH4 conversion over photocatalysts. As further evidence, hot H2O vapor with similar temperature was directly injected into the reaction system to replace PM. The conversion efficiency of CO2 to CH4 appears to be close to that of TiO2+PM system with similar temperature of hot H2O vapor. Then the CH4 production rate suddenly declined when the temperature of H2O vapor dropped (Fig. 6e and f).

In contrast to the crucial role of p H2O, the effect of p CO2 on the reaction rate appears to be limited. Under constant p H2O, the production of CH4 and CO showed a similar trend with the increase of p CO2 in both TiO2 and TiO2+PM systems (Fig. 7 a and b). The results suggested the same influence of p CO2 on CH4 and CO production, meanwhile, the introduction of PM did not alter the adsorption property of CO2 molecules on the TiO2 surface. At low p CO2 (≤ 2 kPa), the K CO2 •p CO2 value is far less than 1, therefore CO2 coverage on TiO2 surface presents a linear increase with p CO2. Thus the reaction rate is directly proportional to the change of p CO2 in gas mixture, which is in accordance with eq. 3. However, the increase in CH4 and CO production gradually slowed down and then reached a reaction equilibrium state at higher p CO2, presumably due to the entire coverage of CO2 gas molecules on the available catalytic active sites. Obviously, the relationship between r and p CO2 is inapplicable to the competitive adsorption mechanism of eq. 3. The result in the region of p CO2 = 2∼85 kPa implies that the increased CO2 molecules might not occupy the adsorption sites for H2O molecules. H2O molecules were pre-adsorbed on the catalytic sites. Both theoretical calculations and experiment results revealed that CO2 adsorbed weakly on TiO2 surface but the co-adsorption with H2O could increase the CO2 adsorption energy. As reported, water molecules were found to easily adsorb on the Ti sites, leading to the formation of a hydrogen bond between the H2O molecule and one of the O atoms of CO2 [55,56]. In contrast, CO2 molecule is least strongly bound to TiO2 surface in the absence of water. The increased CO2 adsorption in the presence of co-adsorbed H2O has also been confirmed in other systems, such as ZrO2, carbon, metal–organic framework, perovskite, et al. [57–61]. Therefore, the pre-adsorbed H2O molecules on TiO2 surface can facilitate the co-adsorption of CO2 due to the formation of H-bonding, which favored the proton transfer to activate the neighboring CO2 and yield the intermediates of bicarbonate species. On this premise, the value of Ɵ H2O could be considered as a constant under stable T G and p H2O, so the kinetic model can be modified as Eq. (4), which clarified the relationship between r and p CO2.

Based on the above discussions, the conversion efficiency strongly depends on the partial pressure of H2O vapor and CH4 evolution rate obviously increased in a broad region of p H2O = 2∼43 kPa, whereas its dependence on the partial pressure of CO2 was only observed in a limited region (≤ 2 kPa). The results reflected that higher H2O coverage favored its activation on the catalyst surface, which played a dominant role in the reaction with the adsorbed CO2 molecules, as illustrated in Fig. 1. Thus the kinetically sluggish water oxidation reaction could be dramatically promoted. As further evidence, Fig. 7c presented a much higher O2 production rate (41.3 μmol g−1 h−1) in TiO2+PM system. The O2 production occurred in a 4-electron transfer process, so the electrons from water oxidation reaction are equivalent to the those that were consumed during CO2 reduction. The simultaneous monitoring of CH4, CO and O2 production verifies the overall redox reaction over TiO2 photocatalyst with assitence of PM-induced water steam generation, achieving enhanced effiicency for CO2 reduction and H2O oxidation, much higher than the reported values over various kinds of TiO2 and other photocatalysts in literatures (Table S2). The theoretical study discovered that the protons were transferred concertedly with two electrons to the linear CO2 to form a CO molecule, which was strongly adsorbed and further reduced to CH4 on anatase TiO2 surface [62]. The CH4 production could be promoted by the additional introduction CO (Fig. S15). As a result, the mechanism for CO2 reduction involved multiple steps, (1) the adsorbed H2O being dissociated to produce protons as the first step, (2) the proton being transferred to CO2 and the protonated CO2 being decomposed to CO, (3) the strongly adsorbed CO being hydrogenated and deoxygenation to form CH4 as final product.

In summary, the present work focused on the impact of H2O vapor on the photocatalytic CO2 reduction. It has been demonstrated that the CO2 conversion efficiency strongly depends on the partial pressure of H2O vapor, whereas its dependence on the partial pressure of CO2 was only observed in a limited region (≤ 2 kPa). Thanks to a photothermal effect of PPy membrane, the well-designed TiO2+PM system accelerated H2O evaporation to increase the reaction temperature at surface catalytic sites from 73 to 86 °C and partial pressure of H2O vapor from 17 to 43 kPa at normal pressure, among which the latter contributed more to the selective reduction of CO2 to CH4. Through the temperature and concentration-dependent kinetic experiments, the adsorption mechanism on the photocatalyst surface has been modified as the preferential H2O adsorption mode to replace the previously assumed competitive adsorption between CO2 and H2O. The H2O molecules were pre-adsorbed on the Ti sites of TiO2 surface to the formation of H-bonding with CO2 molecules. Then the H2O molecules were dissociated to provide protons for the activation of the neighboring CO2 molecules and yield the intermediates of bicarbonate species.With the assistance of PM-induced light-to-heat conversion, the light energy can be more efficiently utilized for water vapor production together with the photogeneration of charge carriers. This work not only presents new insights into understanding the roles of CO2 and H2O vapor in the solid-gas photocatalytic system and also opens up an intriguing way to enhance the efficiency and selectivity for CO2 conversion.
